StudyAbout: This study is about how candidates' answers to questions that require them to put themselves in a bad light affect the perspectives and impressions that interviewers have of them, for instance their character, attitudes, whether they are capable of admitting their faults, and how competent the candidate will be in the job he/she is being interviewed for.
Gender_Aware_Des: Gender should generally not affect someone's job capabilities.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: The candidate appeared to be simply annoyed/ angry that the deal went wrong because Chris was late and he was the one with the presentation materials, perhaps showing that the fault was Chris' and not hers. I got the impression that the candidate was either unaware that she was part of the problem or that she did not want to admit that that it was partly her fault, since she could have ensured both Chris and her got to the venue on time by for instance, riding in the same car and giving sufficient transportation time. The candidate perhaps did not reflect on her mistakes but instead was more fixated on her anger at Chris.

The reason would be it was just sad rather than regret or guilty, so I do not see the sense of responsibility from the candidate's sharing.

StudyAbout:
This is a study that figures out how HR/Hiring Managers perceive candidates based on various psychometric and fit questions.

The weakness question is a common one, and should be answered carefully. I assume Karen Chua is a relationship manager, perhaps at a bank (which she lost the account of). In this case, for RMs, impression counts (big time probably). The weakness she highlighted as not an ideal one as it may perhaps serve as a dealbreaker given that it directly shows that she failed to manage relationships (as an RM). I'm sure she could have done many things better (which she did not even raise). Hence, the dealbreaker weakness + failure to raise how she has changed/learnt from the experience will make us as survey candidates feel that she is unfit for the role.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: I felt that she emphasized the fact that she was "sad" from the incident, focusing on her emotions rather than rational thought (i.e. "i felt that what went wrong was that we failed to account for possibility that the traffic would be bad, or that the client was highlighted to be impatient"). Gave me an impression of weak internal locus of control and an emotional candidate (not the ideal type for a RM role).

StudyAbout: This study is about how quickly do we form impression about people based on one situation.
I think the study was about examining how the use of negative questions can gives the interviewer important clues about the personality and competency of the job candidate.
Gender_Aware_Des: I did not take the gender of the candidate into consideration while rating the candidate.
Emotion_Aware_Desc:
When the interviewer asked the candidate about how he felt after he left the meeting, the candidate replied that he felt really sad about it. 
I felt that he should have given a response on a self-reflection instead. 
For example, he could have share about how he can improve and ensure that the same mistake will not happen again in the future. 
Therefore, the way the candidate expressed his emotion makes me feel as if he was crying over spilled milk which implies that he might have low competency to handle unexpected situations.

After reading the scenario, it seemed as though the person being interviewed for the job answered the question incorrectly. The question did not ask whether or not her coworker had any negative factors but which ones did she have. Instead of focusing on herself, she blamed someone else. I think this study is about how we perceive ourselves and how entitled people are when they think that is "perfect". This woman obviously went around the question and states a positive about herself so that she didn't look bad in front of the interviewer and that sort of shows how vulnerable we are by the control that others hold over us in times of uncertainty.
Gender_Aware_Des: In some interesting way, when the woman described the mishap that happened between her and her male coworker, my image of her changed. I imagined her as a stuck up person who instead of making light of the situation and being more understanding, only made the situation worse. I feel that society has a way of making women seem like they have a big attitude and the way the scenario was described definitely swayed my opinion. I also did not realize this before reading the previous question.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: After she was asked how she felt, the woman stated that she felt, "annoyed." I am sure that her coworker did not mean to be late and she could've done something to save the account. Instead of being frustrated at her coworker, she could've taken the time while waiting for him to keep the account holder interested in something to pass the time. At times we can not control the actions of others but the way we respond to them can change the way we view the situation. I understand that she was frustrated but being annoyed did not help anyone and they lost the account anyway.

StudyAbout: This study was about how job interviewers perceive applicants at a job interview. This situation gave a student, like me, insight on how an interviewer can ask one tricky question in the interview that might have a major impact on how the interviewer views you afterward, and eventually whether your fit for the job now depending on any out-of-pocket answers the applicant might've provided to the question that makes the interviewer now hesitant to hire the applicant. We see second-hand the type of questions that can be asked in an interview that attempt at tricking up or setting up the applicant for failure. We are now educated and should prepare ourselves for these types of questions in interviews to make good first impressions and increase chances of getting hired.
Gender_Aware_Des: N/A I'm not biased or sexist.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: I guess you could say that it sort of did. I guess since I'm more of an empathetic human, I relate to this woman's struggle, as she is being completely honest and vulnerable with her response, which I respect. That's why I feel like, if I were the interviewer, no matter if she had a hiccup in the past, that she would improve and I see improvement in her as she exemplifies a great core value (for a worker) of honesty and integrity, as she takes accountability for her mistakes in the past and saying how she felt "so so sad", not trying to sugar coat the defeat she was feeling. She gets personal with us, not trying to display how flawless or errorless she is.

StudyAbout: I think this study was about our beliefs about a job applicant after they answered a negative question, which made them talk about something negative about themselves
Emotion_Aware_Desc: I believe the fact that the candidate described her feeling "sad" after they lost the client influenced my ratings. This is because this was a quite serious situation, where the company she worked for might have lost thousands of pounds and the fact that she only felt "sad" suggests she does not understand the importance of this loss. It also suggests she believed there was nothing that could be done. For instance, she didn't feel frustrated or angry at her coworker, which makes me think she believed the situation to be inevitable and that there was nothing that could be done, even though she could possibly give a small presentation to the clients without the materials her coworker was supposed to bring. Overall, the use of the word "sad" just made me think of her as a quite passive person.

StudyAbout: looking at whether negative questions in interviews are useful indicators of applicants abilities

To assess the utility of questions that employers commonly ask in interviews to gain an understanding and picture of the interviewee. Analysing participants' responses will help reflect on whether the conclusions drawn from answers are fair, and whether the questions and number of questions asked ensure employers get a fuller picture of the interviewee.

StudyAbout: This study was about whether we can make inferences about a person based on a description of their reaction in a particular situation. Singular incidents might sometimes provide us with good insight on whether a person will meet our expectations (like a 'blink'). On the other hand, a singular description of someone's response might be very misguided and lead us to biased or very wrong inferences, especially if we extrapolate one incident and assume it to reflect on a person's behavior or ability. Maybe if we had access to more information on their answers or about their previous role and responsibilities, we would be able to make more accurate predictions about their personality and what their wage should be. Also, we do not have much information on the role they are applying for so it is hard to come up with a number for their wage, and that number comes almost arbitrarily. Having knowledge of general wage ranges would also affect our judgement as one does not always know what wage correlates to what type of work.
Gender_Aware_Des: I did notice the 'her' in the statement but focused on the rest of the information when trying to rate the candidate. So, I believe it did not influence me as I was trying to focus on the rest of the information provided. I do not think the gender influenced my decision.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: The emotion was 'sad'. Although this shows that the candidate cared for the job, for me this is not an extremely strong emotion so it influenced my decision when rating them as 'cold' or 'warm'. Maybe if that assignment was really important to them they would have felt 'frustrated' or 'devastated', i.e. mention a more intense emotion for dissatisfaction or sadness with the outcome.

StudyAbout:
Initially according to your introduction to the study, I thought it was about how decisions/answers effect the prespective of the interviewer, and how a negative answer can result in employability. 

But gradually, the questions tend to shift the study towards character formations and derivation based on a spectrum of issues. Deducing from an answer, with the invisible factors in the background the study finds out what a response to a situations or decision making can mean.
Decidestudyabout: While I was rating the candidate
Gender_Aware_Des: I did not take gender in account at all.
Emotion_Aware_Desc:
Emotions drives a person to decide.
And an emotional response tells us about what the intention of the person were, if he was not the sole authority to make decision. 

Other factors, like the coworker not being able to arrive, was not under the candidates control but how he/she responds to it emotions tells a lot about the person.

StudyAbout: I think the prompt indicated that the male applicant was leaning towards blaming what went wrong in this situation on his female colleagues. This is not apparent but it was very subtle. I could almost read - females are bad drivers but I maybe imagining a little too far here.
Decidestudyabout: Before I rated the candidate
Gender_Aware_Des:
I think the answer given by the applicant, Rahul, cleverly portrays a situation where he didn't do anything wrong. Things just happened. The cause was external. The incident, infact, averts the answer the recruiter is looking for - which is to understand if a person can own up mistakes in workplace. 

The fact that the applicant was a guy biased me to believe that he was subtly blaming his female colleagues for the negative consequences in his situation. 

This bias is reinforced by my personal experiences where men at my workplace are quick to externalise their failures and I have been a victim to such thought process.

StudyAbout: My attitude towards what kind of behaviour should be rewarded among male and female - white-collar workers
Decidestudyabout: While I was rating the candidate
Gender_Aware_Des:
A male colleague demeaning a female colleague, scapegoating, blame-gaming. 
A male colleague has all 'directions' (decision making/ instructions), and a female colleague has done all the background work ('preparing material for presentation').
Putting all the blame on only one member of a team would anyway have made me prejudiced against that person, the stereotype of a male blaming female- just made the influence stronger.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: He was 'angry'. Instead of managing the client, instead of thinking that he should have had at least knowledge enough of the background material/ presentation - that he could have made an extempore presentation, instead of thinking how such a situation would not arise in future, instead of owning up his role in the loss of that account, instead of worrying about the colleague- why she could not reach, instead of trying to reach her over the phone and making a virtual presentation if possible, instead of so many other ways he could have handled the situation to prevent damage, he is just 'angry'. And he is blaming a colleague behind their back- at another company - also mentions the name of the colleague - thus defaming her at other places of potential work/ employers..

StudyAbout: Trying to understand how we make an impression about someone without knowing more details

StudyAbout:
The study was about the first impressions we create after interviews with applicants. Based on the response to questions during an interview, we create impressions related to power, salaries, competency. 

However, at no point during my entire process of filling this survey, would I have changed my answers if the candidate was a male. I think this survey is forcefully trying to make this about gender. I thought about every question in two ways - once if the candidate was male and once if the candidate was female. My answers would have been exactly the same.

While I was rating the candidate

StudyAbout: I was told that this study is about gender perception. I dont know how this study relates to the gender. But I dont like this guy Rahul Patel at all! He could have chosen to divide the material in 2, he could have handled the client better in voicing over the materials if he were that well versed. What is the use of putting all of this on his poor co-worker ?
Decidestudyabout: While I was rating the candidate
SS_describe: I have never faced such a kind of case study before. I do not know what this case study is about.
Gender_Aware_Des:
I am a woman, and I am not one from a privileged background. So I have faced a lot of discrimination in life and I support when women raise their voices. 

And that is why here I think the gender played a role. Rahul Patel seems to be a man, and when he loses his patience, calls out his co-worker, uses words like "annoyance", I assume he is an entitled spoiled brat (have met too many in life). He could have copied the materials (that should be done!), left together, managed time better, managed client better, and so on and so forth. 

But he didn't admit any of it. He directly blamed his co-worker. 

But what if it were a woman? I think I would still think the above line items, but probably I wouldnt be that harsh on her, given she is atleast brave enough to voice her opinions. 

I would not call it sexism or favoritism. This is because women have already been criticised for being "bossy". While being leader is good, and bossy is not, I would prefer a bossy woman over a submissive woman. But when it comes to men, men are in general more commanding and entitled. So I would prefer a humble man over a commanding man in general.

I cannot compare where both of them are. But I sure can compare the distance - how far they have traveled.
Emotion_Aware_Desc: Explained above already.

Decidestudyabout: While I was rating the candidate

Emotion_Aware_Desc: The emotions he expressed are important, because they show his mindset when faced with adversity. In this particular situation, his anger at his colleague showed that he took little to no responsibility for losing the client account, and was willing to blame it on his colleague.

StudyAbout: Im not quite sure it could be for a range of different purposes. Emotion_Aware_Desc: Sad? Well, thats an unexpected feeling to have after such incident. She could have been angry, which would have shown that she was superior to Matin, and thus angry at him for not fulfilling his responsibilities. She could have been upset for missing a good opportunity by not thinking ahead about things. She could have been frustrated if this was her own business. But then of all the emotions she was sad? That just to me sounds like such an irresponsible feeling to have. There is no thinking or remorse in sadness, nor any hint that something was learnt and she will now go to meetings more prepared. You can be sad when someone passes away, when there is nothing you can do to change the situation but there were actually many ways she could have resolved this problem or at least learned from this incident but it just doesnt seem that she has.

StudyAbout:
I think this study is about working adults' perception of a job applicant's position/ qualification and how they will perform in their applied job based on their answer to a difficult question in the job interview. 

The questions asked by the study also show that interviewers may have a range of perceptions about a candidate that go way beyond the scope of the question and not based on any prior interaction / knowledge about the candidate.
Gender_Aware_Des: I didn't realize it but this question brought to my awareness that gender might have influenced how I rated the candidate. Perhaps because he is a male employee, I expect him to be in control of such a professional situation, and hence, rate him low in the "in control" question. I may have been a bit more understanding if the candidate was a female.
Emotion_Aware_Desc:
I think the emotion he expresses is the biggest clue in my ratings. He doesn't express any other emotions but "sadness", which informs me in rating him low on "in control" because he doesn't seem to be thinking how to resolve the situation. He expresses a very passive emotion. This relates to how I rate him on the position he should be entitled and his salary because it gives me the impression that he is at an entry level position and is somebody's subordinate.

 However, it also prompts me to see him as exuding "warmth" rather than coldness and makes him seem "likeable" to me. 

I also relate sadness to a sense of regret, so him expressing sadness doesn't stop me from hiring him.

StudyAbout:
This study outcome is whether I would hire the candidate and how much he should be paid

The aim is probably to show that interviews are subjective and not reliable in choosing candidates

Being sad means accepting bad things instead of knowing what to do when the same scenario occurs

StudyAbout: i think the study is above how competent and how confident a candidate is at work, whether a small issue can make the candidate feel like it's something very big to him and feeling sad at work.

I think this was about gauging competency for senior positions based on the interview answers. E.G. In looking back at losing the account, is the candidate expressing analysis, willingness to ensure it doesn't happen again, remorse perhaps? But most importantly, ability to move forward and express/show actions they took to make sure something similar doesn't occur.

The other thing this study could be about is gender discrimination - knowing that the candidate is a female, do we think she deserves to get paid less, and see the loss of the company's account more seriously than if she was male. Also, the fact that she says, "i was sad..." may feed the subconscious bias of people thinking that women = emotional, and therefore not as competent as men.
Gender_Aware_Des: I try to be conscious about any judgements I make based on gender, even more so if they are female-related (I'm a woman so maybe I'm more aware/pick up on it), but at the same time, I'm not sure if there were any other hidden stereotypes that may have influenced m answer. Also, initially when reading it, I assumed it would be a male. I only realised it's a female when it mentioned, "she/her."
Emotion_Aware_Desc: If I was a hiring manager, I would expect some form of willingness/drive from the candidate to ensure it doesn't happen again. Everyone makes mistakes, and sometimes bad days just happen. But by saying, "i felt sad," it made me think that the candidate was unable to practice foresight, or able to adapt or overcome to look ahead to prevent such mistakes. If they outlined the actions they took afterwards, and some examples to ensure it didn't happen, it shows recovery, adaptability and the ability to not be easily deterred. Then you'd feel comfortable giving responsibility to someone like that. I also though, am not sure if the candidate is perhaps someone who is introverted, shy, or perhaps isn't expressive. If there's a language issue at play, perhaps the candidate isn't able to find the right words to express everything - and that isn't fair to judge competence.

splitting the documents between two people is often seen with female workers who are on friendly terms. society tends to be lenient on females as there is somewhat of an impression that females are a bit air headed and act on emotion. During first hand experience of handing in assignments, female partners often suggested splitting the work. Male partners however designated one person to deliver. 
Males are perceived to be more cool headed, rational and strategic. There should always be a plan b and plan c. This is a very simple yet grave mistake. The candidate should have anticipated any issues and not have risked splitting the documents.

This study was to showcase how when clients are given a question with a negative connotation of how it affects the development and continuation of the interview. I think it may be linked to team effort. Perhaps personal accountability even in difficult situations. Also, maybe it was to see how particular applicants would be viewed in the face of adverse challenges which are "out of their control". 
Perhaps an element of planning of mapping would be a consideration of a potential employer. And maybe it's to gauge mood fluctuations to see if the candidate would be expressive or amiable. I think that by me judging her responses, it shows that we do still have a slightly negative bias (even though we weren't there when the tense situation happened). We will pre-empt how controlled someone is of their emotions just listening to a past story.
Gender_Aware_Des: I am a woman and I hate saying this but I have worked with highly emotional and type A women who I have been afraid to sit near when they have experienced something negative with a client. HOWEVER I have seen men have similar meltdowns in the office as well. I don't really know why I am judging her when I wasn't even in the room and couldn't hear the tone of her voice but I think if they'd planned this better then wouldn't each of them have programmed the address into their GPS/google maps before leaving the office?
Emotion_Aware_Desc: As previously stated, I didn't like that there was an underlying "blame shift". What I mean is, it was a team effort and both parties needed to have the logistics in place prior to arriving at their meeting. It was a rookie error and both are culpable. I wasn't there to hear the tone but it felt like blame. Gender_Aware_Des: Da ich mir bewusst bin, dass Frauen aufgrund ihres Geschlechts im professionellen Umfeld diskriminiert werden, hinterfrage ich aktivierte Schemata besonders kritisch. Das hat natrlich einen Einfluss darauf, wie ich die Situation bewerte. (As I am aware that women are discriminated against in the professional environment because of their gender, I am particularly critical of activated schemes. This naturally has an influence on how I evaluate the situation.)
Emotion_Aware_Desc: Die Antwort, dass die Bewerberin wtend war, zeigt auf der einen Seite Offenheit, auf der anderen Seite wurde wenig reflexives ber das Gefhl vermittelt, was mich an der Fhigkeit solche Gefhle zu reflektieren zweifeln lsst. (The answer that the applicant was angry shows on the one hand openness, on the other hand little reflection on the feeling was given, which makes me doubt the ability to reflect such feelings.)
